title: Marine A, Sergeant Alexander Blackman in powerful coutroom statement as he launches bid to overturn murder conviction for shooting Taliban soldier
text:
Opinion 'ONLY THOSE WHO'VE BEEN ON THE FRONT LINE KNOW' Marine A, Sergeant Alexander Blackman in powerful coutroom statement as he launches bid to overturn murder conviction for shooting Taliban soldier 
The Royal Marine was 'dismissed with disgrace' after the shooting By BRITTANY VONOW and CATHY GORDON 7th February 2017, 1:10 pm Click to share on Facebook (Opens in new window) Comments A ROYAL Marine who was sentenced to life behind bars for the fatal shooting of a wounded Taliban fighter has been likened to the famed Western actor John Wayne. 
In Sergeant Alexander Blackman’s latest appeal for freedom, the court heard that the man had been plagued by “mental scars” after facing death everyday while on the front lines in Afghanistan. PA:Press Association Former Royal Marine Sergeant Alexander Blackman was found guilty of murdering the Afghani soldier PA:Press Association 5 Claire Blackman, the wife of Alexander Blackman, arrived at the High Court for the appeal on Tuesday morning 
Jonathan Goldberg opened the new appeal against the Royal Marine’s sentencing, saying the conditions that those within the Plymouth-based 42 Commando faced in the Helmand province were “austere” and a “breeding ground” for mental health problems. 
He said: “Only those who have been on the front line can know what it is really like.” 
He added that Blackman had almost been killed by a grenade himself, while also losing a close friend, saying: “Mr Blackman’s nature is to be very reserved. He is a sort of John Wayne character.” PA:Press Association Supporters gathered outside the court on Tuesday morning before the appeal began Supporter of 'Marine A' Alexander Blackman at High Court for bail hearing 
The court heard that the Taliban were "ruthless and cunning", with shooting incidents often happening on a daily basis. 
The QC argued that Blackman had "endured" the loss of a young company officer "with whom he had been on very close terms" and had mentored, with the toll that the marine experienced at the heart of the appeal. 
The opening case comes after the Criminal Cases Review Commission (CCRC), which investigates potential miscarriages of justice, said his legal team carried out "inadequate" preparations for his 2013 court martial. 
The CCRC announced it had concluded that a number of new issues, including fresh evidence relating to Blackman's mental state, ''raise a real possibility'' that the Court Martial Appeal Court ''will now quash Mr Blackman's murder conviction''. 
Only those who have been on the front line can know what it is really like Jonathan Goldberg QC 
The most recent conviction challenge is being heard by Lord Chief Justice Lord Thomas, Sir Brian Leveson, Lady Justice Hallett, Mr Justice Openshaw and Mr Justice Sweeney, with the proceedings expected to last three days. 
His wife Claire and dozens of supporters attended the first day of the appeal, with jailed Blackman watching the proceedings via videolink from prison. 
Blackman was previously convicted in November 2013 by a court martial in Bulford, Wiltshire, and sentenced to life with a minimum term of 10 years. 
His minimum term was reduced to eight years during an appeal in May 2014, with it found he was suffering from combat stress disorder at the time of the 2011 shooting. 
Blackman applied for bail in December 2016, pending the appeal, but the move was rejected by two judges.
